resource descriptions.descriptionText: PubMed is a searchable database of medical literature and lists journal articles that discuss Florid cemento-osseous dysplasia. Click on the link to view a sample search on this topic.
The Centers for Mendelian Genomics program is working to discover the causes of rare genetic disorders. For more information about applying to the research study, please visit their website.

To find a medical professional who specializes in genetics, you can ask your doctor for a referral or you can search for one yourself. Online directories are provided by the American College of Medical Genetics and the National Society of Genetic Counselors. If you need additional help, contact a GARD Information Specialist. You can also learn more about genetic consultations from Genetics Home Reference.
Orphanet is a European reference portal for information on rare diseases and orphan drugs. Access to this database is free of charge.

overviewQuestion.answerText:
Florid cemento-osseous dysplasia (FCOD) is a condition that occurs in the jaw bone, especially close to where the teeth are formed.[15058][15059] People with FCOD develop lesions in the jaw, were spots of normal bone are replaced with a mix of connective tissue and abnormal bone.[15058][15060] The lesions are often found in equal numbers and size on both sides of the jaw. People with FCOD rarely have symptoms and it is usually found with dental x-rays during a routine dental examination.

The cause of FCOD is unknown, and it does not usually run in families. It mainly occurs in middle aged women of African American and Asian descent.[15058][15059] The number, size, and shape of the lesions can be different from person to person. Occasionally the lesions expand or get infected and may cause discomfort, pain, or mild disfigurement.[15058][15059] Treatment for this condition is observation and avoiding infections of the mouth and teeth. The long-term outlook for people with FCOD is good.

basicQuestions.questionText: What are the signs and symptoms of florid cemento-osseous dysplasia?
basicQuestions.answerText: Usually florid cemento-osseous dysplasia causes no symptoms. It is often found by accident while getting dental x-rays for some other purpose.[15059] Occasionally however, the lesions get infected and may expand causing discomfort, pain, and/or mild disfigurement.[15059]

references.authors: Fenerty S, Shaw W, Verma R, Syed AB, Kuklani R, Yang J, Ali S
references.articleTitle: Florid cemento-osseous dysplasia: review of an uncommon fibro-osseous lesion of the jaw with important clinical implications

basicQuestions.answerText: The cause of florid cemento-osseous dysplasia (FCOD) is not known.[15058][15059]

references.authors: Das BK, Das SN, Gupta A, Nayak S
Fenerty S, Shaw W, Verma R, Syed AB, Kuklani R, Yang J, Ali S
references.articleTitle: Florid cemento-osseous dysplasia: review of an uncommon fibro-osseous lesion of the jaw with important clinical implications

basicQuestions.questionText: How is florid cemento-osseous dysplasia inherited?
basicQuestions.answerText: Florid cemento-osseous dysplasia (FCOD) doesn't typically run in families. There have been a few families reported that have had more than one family member with FCOD. In these families, the condition occurs at younger ages and the lesions grow faster than in FCOD seen in people with no family history of the condition.[15059][15061]

references.authors: Fenerty S, Shaw W, Verma R, Syed AB, Kuklani R, Yang J, Ali S
references.articleTitle: Florid cemento-osseous dysplasia: review of an uncommon fibro-osseous lesion of the jaw with important clinical implications

references.authors: Consolaro A, Paschoal SRB, Ponce JB, Miranda DAO
references.articleTitle: Florid cemento-osseous dysplasia: a contraindication to orthodontic treatment in compromised areas

basicQuestions.questionText: How is florid cemento-osseous dysplasia diagnosed?
basicQuestions.answerText:
Diagnosis of florid cemento-osseous dysplasia (FCOD) relies on the x-ray findings of the lesions as well as the clinical signs and symptoms. FCOD can look like other, more serious conditions, and it's important to make sure that FCOD is the correct diagnosis.[15059] Other conditions that can look like FCOD include: 
  • Paget's disease
  • Chronic diffuse sclerosing osteomyelitis
  • Fibrous dysplasia
  • Osterosarcoma
  • Periapical cemental dysplasia
  • Infections

references.authors: Fenerty S, Shaw W, Verma R, Syed AB, Kuklani R, Yang J, Ali S
references.articleTitle: Florid cemento-osseous dysplasia: review of an uncommon fibro-osseous lesion of the jaw with important clinical implications

basicQuestions.answerText: In most people, florid cemento-osseous dysplasia (FCOD) does not require treatment. People with this condition should be followed with dental x-rays every 2-3 years.[15059][15060][15061] In addition, because infections are difficult to treat in people with FCOD, sometimes people with FCOD take antibiotics to help prevent infections.  If someone with FCOD does get an infection of the jaw, treatment may include surgery to clean out the infection.[15059]

references.authors: Fenerty S, Shaw W, Verma R, Syed AB, Kuklani R, Yang J, Ali S
references.articleTitle: Florid cemento-osseous dysplasia: review of an uncommon fibro-osseous lesion of the jaw with important clinical implications

references.articleTitle: Florid cemento-osseous dysplasia: a contraindication to orthodontic treatment in compromised areas

basicQuestions.questionText: What is the long-term outlook for people with florid cemento-osseous dysplasia?
basicQuestions.answerText: People with florid cemento-osseous dysplasia (FCOD) do not usually have any symptoms from their condition. FCOD makes people more likely to get infections in the teeth and jaw. It is difficult to treat those infections with antibiotics and surgery may be necessary to remove the infection.[15059] The long-term outlook for people with this condition is generally good.

references.authors: Fenerty S, Shaw W, Verma R, Syed AB, Kuklani R, Yang J, Ali S
references.articleTitle: Florid cemento-osseous dysplasia: review of an uncommon fibro-osseous lesion of the jaw with important clinical implications

basicQuestions.questionText: How many people have florid cemento-osseous dysplasia?
basicQuestions.answerText: Florid cemento-osseous dysplasia (FCOD) usually African-American women in their mid-40s.[15058][15059][15061] Asian women are more likely to develop this condition, but both men and women of other ethnicities have been reported with FCOD. While the exact prevalence is unknown, the literature reports that about 5.5% of black women may have FCOD.[15061]

news.title: NIH-Supported Research Survey to Examine Impact of COVID-19 on Rare Diseases Community
news.description: The NIH-funded Rare Diseases Clinical Research Network (RDCRN) has launched an online research survey to find out how the COVID-19 pandemic is impacting individuals with rare diseases, their families and their caregivers. Your participation can help the rare disease research community shed light on the needs of people with rare diseases during this and other potential health crises, in addition to informing future research efforts. The survey must be completed by December 15, 2020.
